conclusion: Car A is coming from the right-hand edge with moderate speed and a shallow angle aimed just above the single yellow cube that lies lowest in the field.
The single yellow cube is isolated and lies lowest in the field.
Because the yellow cube is isolated and has low mass, the car will strike it first.
The yellow cube will be pushed left-upward and the car will lose only a little speed.
There is a loose cluster of small red-and-orange cubes near the yellow cube.
The carâ€™s path then continues into the loose cluster of small red-and-orange cubes.
Friction and multiple light impacts with the red-and-orange cubes will slow the car quickly.
There are denser stacks of green and yellow cubes further ahead.
Before the car can reach the denser green or yellow stacks, its remaining kinetic energy is spent and it rolls to a stop among the small red/orange cubes.
A collides first with the single yellow cube, then with the nearby loose red-orange cubes, and finally comes to rest in that red/orange area, short of the green and tall yellow stacks.
